BAA1641BA36E48309FED5E29417232E9.description: Assess archaeological evidence for the emergence of complex belief systems, including widespread worship of female deities.

FB4C3D5D59A7479AB9FBCBF704453B45.description: Analyze archaeological evidence from agricultural village sites in different regions of the world indicating the emergence of social class divisions, occupational specializations, and differences in the daily tasks that men and women performed.

94C033A458644AE5B7C275154D83D850.description: Analyze how peoples of the world domesticated food plants and developed agricultural communities in response to local needs and conditions, including the rise of of long-distance trade systems.

027C437CE86E4F2285D3C3EE4D0FB9C3.description: Describe social, cultural, and economic characteristics of large agricultural settlements.

A0349AD9CEC240A9983232C0CC02A9DF.description: Analyze differences between hunter-gatherer and agrarian communities in economy, social organization, and quality of living.

248B995AB729412DB93478B9AEA007E2.description: Define and understand the characteristics of the 1st agricultural revolution.

E125EBA315234F32B0092B5509D2CB68.description: The student understands how agricultural societies developed around the world.

42D3814B72554D799B6FBFC06BA4103D.description: Apply the five characteristics of civilization to the study of the Mesopotamia: technology, record keeping, cities, specialization, and institutions.

3BEB60CA61CE4F01B45B4532E5E66F75.description: Identify areas in the Fertile Crescent (through Mesopotamia) where early farming communities probably appeared and analyze the environmental and technological factors that made possible experiments with farming in these regions.

7530736BF1F8420C9CAFB0C5BD82FFBD.description: Describe leading theories to explain how and why human groups domesticated wild grains as well as cattle, sheep, goats, and pigs after the last Ice Age.

784C2CC46BB94EBE944F0C4987CACDDB.description: Describe types of evidence and methods of investigation by which scholars have reconstructed the early history of domestication and agricultural settlement.

312E9498B3384D12A3A299711A332238.description: Infer from archaeological evidence the technology, social organization, and cultural life of settled farming communities Fertile Crescent, through Mesopotamia.

4CACAFB385C14DB69188701157CA6245.description: The student understands how and why humans established settled communities and experimented with agriculture.

40A6079191C94E1A8CDE4DA947AC13F8.description: Analyze possible links between environmental conditions associated with the last Ice Age and changes in the economy, culture, and organization of human communities.

76C0C07069FB4AE5AE6CD238E994EE72.description: Infer from archaeological evidence the characteristics of Cro-Magnon hunter-gatherer communities of western Eurasia including tool kits, shelter, clothing, ritual life, aesthetic values, relations between men and women, and trade among communities.

19381BA3813347568FA230B3338DE8A4.description: Assess theories regarding the development of human language and its relationship to the development of culture.

81E1DEA68BE0400588F4197BBC733F95.description: Compare the way of life of hunter-gatherer communities in Africa, the Americas, and western Eurasia and explain how such communities in different parts of the world responded creatively to local environments.

9E8F3462FC9C4999A359DE0800B4FFD3.description: Analyze current and past theories regarding the emergence of Homo sapiens sapiens and the processes by which human ancestors migrated from Africa to the other major world regions.

2CB34F824B4F458FAEBCCAE0DDD56E36.description: The student understands how human communities populated the major regions of the world and adapted to a variety of environments.

4491027D257F4AF99AA5A49A44CBA0D5.description: Trace the approximate chronology, sequence, and territorial range of early hominid evolution; ie, Lucy, Handyman, Upright Man, Neanderthal, and Cro-Magnon.

8A6A0DC7840F41DEAC9DBF06D11746DA.description: Describe types of evidence and methods of investigation that anthropologists, archaeologists, and other scholars have used to reconstruct early human evolution and cultural development.

FE15CD28008C44629FC806CCB78DDD39.description: Infer from archaeological evidence the characteristics of early African hunter-gatherer communities, including tool kits, shelter, diet, and use of fire.

74356A3D5568458BA739B852A2E75CA4.description: The student understands early hominid development in Africa.

FF66AC672D5F4014885A2C83480CC433.description: Identify geographical processes of Earth that led to the theory of Pangea and the continental drift.

CC0ED61352104216BE98AAF6CFE41D8D.description: Compare and contrast the five themes of geography: location, place, movement, human environment interaction, and region, in different areas of the world.

C1EC4B7CC6B8483BB0D73F9BC029C138.description: Apply the five themes of geography: location, place, movement, human environment interaction, and region, to different areas of the world.

912D8F7575B741128B16E0206D852123.description: Students understands how to use the five themes of Geography to explore different areas of the world.
